conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the difference in displacement between two objects A and B during the time interval from 0 to t₁ using their velocity-time graphs.

The velocity-time graphs show two parabolic curves for objects A and B, with A following the upper curve and B following the lower curve. Both curves start at the origin (0,0) and end at time t₁ where v = 0.
The area under each v-t curve represents the displacement of the respective object.
The difference in displacement between objects A and B at time t can be expressed as Δs(t) = s_A(t) - s_B(t).
For Δs(t) to be continuously increasing, its derivative with respect to time, dΔs(t)/dt, must be positive for all t in [0, t₁].
dΔs(t)/dt = ds_A(t)/dt - ds_B(t)/dt = v_A(t) - v_B(t). This means Δs(t) increases when v_A(t) > v_B(t).
From the graphs, at t = 0, both objects start with v = 0. For all t between 0 and t₁, v_A(t) > v_B(t) as the upper curve is always above the lower curve. At t = t₁, both velocities return to 0.
Since v_A(t) > v_B(t) for all t in (0, t₁), the derivative of Δs(t) is always positive in this interval.
The red shaded area in the second image represents the difference in displacement between objects A and B.
Since v_A > v_B at every moment, object A is gaining more displacement than object B throughout the entire interval.
The difference in displacement between the two objects is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t₁ because v_A(t) > v_B(t) for all t in (0, t₁).
